articles.description:
Ted Unangst published dude, where are your syscalls? on flak
yesterday, with a neat demonstration of OpenBSD‚Äôs pinsyscall
security feature, whereby only pre-registered addresses are allowed to
make system calls. Whether it strengthens or weakens security is up for
debate, but regardless it‚Äôs an interesting, low-level programming
challenge. The original demo is fragile for multiple reasons, and requires
manually locating and entering addresses for each build. In this article I
show how to fix it. To prove that it‚Äôs robust, I ported an entire, real
application to use raw system calls on OpenBSD.
The original program uses ARM64 assembly. I‚Äôm a lot more comfortable with
x86-64 assembly, plus that‚Äôs the hardware I have readily on hand. So the
assembly language will be different, but all the con‚Ä¶
articles.title: A more robust raw OpenBSD syscall demo

articles.description:
Wavefront OBJ is a line-oriented, text format for 3D geometry. It‚Äôs
widely supported by modeling software, easy to parse, and trivial to emit,
much like Netpbm for 2D image data. Poke around hobby 3D graphics
projects and you‚Äôre likely to find a bespoke OBJ parser. While typically
only loading their own model data, so robustness doesn‚Äôt much matter, they
usually have hard limitations and don‚Äôt stand up to fuzz testing.
This article presents a robust, partial OBJ parser in C with no hard-coded
limitations, written from scratch. Like similar articles, it‚Äôs not
really about OBJ but demonstrating some techniques you‚Äôve probably never
seen before.
If you‚Äôd like to see the ready-to-run full source: objrender.c.
All images are screenshots of this program.
First let‚Äôs establish the requirements. B‚Ä¶
articles.title: Robust Wavefront OBJ model parsing in C

articles.description:
xxd is a versatile hexdump utility with a ‚Äúreverse‚Äù feature, originally
written between 1990‚Äì1996. The Vim project soon adopted it, and it‚Äôs lived
there ever since. If you have Vim, you also have xxd. Its primary use
cases are (1) the basis for a hex editor due to its -r reverse option
that can unhexdump its previous output, and (2) a data embedding tool
for C and C++ (-i). The former provides Vim‚Äôs rudimentary hex editor
functionality. The second case is of special interest to w64devkit:
xxd -i appears in many builds that embed arbitrary data. It‚Äôs
important that w64devkit has a compatible implementation, and a freshly
rewritten, improved xxd, rexxd, now replaces the original xxd (as
xxd).
For those unfamiliar with xxd, examples are in order. Its default hexdump
output looks like this:

$‚Ä¶
articles.title: Meet the new xxd for w64devkit: rexxd

articles.description:
I've switched to MacOS after using Linux continuously since 2012 or thereabouts (first Arch, and
then, since 2015, NixOS). This post documents my experience.
articles.title: MacOS for KDE Users

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Let us consider a simple C++ function which divides all values in a range of integers: void divide(std::span<int> i, int d) { for (auto& value : i) { value /= d; } } If the divisor d is known at compile-time, this function can be much faster. E.g., if d is 2, the compiler might ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Speeding up C++ code with template lambdas
articles.title: Speeding up C++ code with template lambdas

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: In practice, the software we write runs on several processors. Unfortunately, much of what we take for granted on a single processor becomes false when there are more than one processor. For example, if two processors modify the same piece of memory, what is the state of the memory after the modifications? It is difficult ‚Ä¶ Continue reading An overview of parallel programming (Go edition)
articles.title: An overview of parallel programming (Go edition)

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Jarred Sumner, the main author of the Bun JavaScript engine, commented a few days ago on X that opening many files on macOS could be slow due to thread contention: ‚Äúyour $5,000 computer is only capable of opening 1 file at a time‚Äù. I was curious and I decided to test it out. I wrote ‚Ä¶ Continue reading How fast can you open 1000 files?
articles.title: How fast can you open 1000 files?

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Convention computer instructions operate on a single piece of data at once (e.g., they can negate an integer or add two integers). For better performance, CPU vendors add support for SIMD instructions. SIMD stands for Single Instruction, Multiple Data. It is a type of parallel processing where a single operation is executed simultaneously on multiple ‚Ä¶ Continue reading AVX-512 gotcha: avoid compressing words to memory with AMD Zen 4 processors
articles.title: AVX-512 gotcha: avoid compressing words to memory with AMD Zen 4 processors

articles.description:
\[
\newcommand{\sketch}{\mathsf{sketch}}
\]
This is a small survey on MinHash-based sketching methods, to go along with my
simd-sketch crate (github, crates.io, docs.rs). See also Cohen (2014) for a previous
small survey.
Goal. SimdSketch should be fast. It is and should remain a conceptually
simple tool, that prefers fast implementations of simple ideas over complex ideas.
For now, it works well for the simple case of relatively high identity
sequences. I may implement more algorithmic variants, but also the API should
remain concise.
articles.title: SimdSketch: a fast bucket sketch

articles.description:
1 De Bruijn graph
 
 
 

Consider an edge-centric De Bruijn graph, where each edge corresponds to a
k-mer, and nodes are the \(k-1\) overlaps between adjacent k-mers. In the figures,
all edges are directed towards the right.




 2 k-mers
 
 
 

The goal is now to store all edges / k-mers of the graph efficiently.
A spectrum preserving string set (SPSS) is a set of strings whose k-mers are
the k-mers of the input graph, that does not contain duplicate k-mers (Rahman and Medvedev 2020).
articles.title: Types of tigs

articles.description:
1 Warming up: A cute prolblem
 
 
 


Given a string, choose one character.

CABAACBD
Given a rotation, choose one character.

ACBDCABA
Can we always choose the same character?
Yes: e.g. the smallest rotation (bd-anchor):

CAB‚ÄãA‚ÄãACBD
ACBDCAB‚ÄãA
1.1 This talk: what if one character is hidden?
 
 
 


Given a string (length \(w\)), choose one character.

CABAACBD‚Äã‚ÄãX
Given a rotation (of the hidden \(w+1\) string), choose one character.

ACBDXCAB‚ÄãA
Can we always choose the same character?
Maybe?

CAB‚ÄãA‚ÄãACBD
ACBDXCAB ü§î
1.2 The answer is no!
 
 
 

C‚ÄãABAACBDX rotations:
